title: Some reflections on “Opening up Education” and “Opening up Slovenia”

presenter: Fred Mulder, UNESCO Chair on Open Educational Resources (OER)

segmentation: So I was asked to give some reflections on what's happening in Slovenia and that.
It's working fine.

Reflection number one is called education wide and it's good to know that opening up education by the European Commission last year and also opening Slovenia is not only about higher education and that's good that it's being set up that way, because even with my UNESCO had on, I would say primary and segregation are even more important than higher education, so it's good to know that opening up education and opening up Slovenia both are covering all educational sectors from primary up to University level.
From formal education to informal learning, and that is of course for getting abroad.
Benefit of opening of education.
For SoC.
That's my first reflection.
The second one is on governmental policies.
Again, it's good to observe that both in the European opening up education initiative and in Slovenia.
There is no limitation to institutional policies and we all know that it's important to.
Addressed a need for governmental policies without governmental policies.

You can still do quite some interesting things, but it's necessary to create a right context for institutions to make it more easy and more appropriate for them to to jump on the wagon so to get full benefit there is a certain need, a definite need for governmental policies, and again, I could refer to UNESCO and to deal with CD.
They performed a survey in 2012 around.

The national policy is government policies and we found that there's a lot of things going on already, but it should certainly be more effort from governments and I'm quite happy that European Commission is urging the government to do something with opening up education that is really necessary so that institutions can can follow up.
The third one is about the terminology, and that's an interesting one.
I mean, it's good to see that the Commission did not use the term open education as an umbrella term, but they choose the term opening up education that is quite different.
It seems a subtle change, but it's an important change because by using the term opening up, you are emphasizing that this is the process we're talking about.

Dynamics we're not talking about aesthetics thing, you're talking about the process and also it's important to realize by using the terminology opening up education, you realize that there is diversity education.
There's not something like a single ideal model for education.
We know that for decades already, we know it from the start of education.
There is no one model which fits all.
So it's good to realize that diversity should be accommodated in all our initiatives, and this brings in I could say something like New Balance in all the things that we're undertaking.
Can you funding?
We all know there's a lot of funding from the Commission going to projects, and the interesting thing was Slovenia is that they are offering a new approach.
Also a new approach for funding.

I would say they're offering a country case and the country case is quite different from just running a number of projects being funded by the Commission by which you can wander what the final impact of all those projects will be.
I sort of slide at which I was presenting.

There's hundreds of projects and you may ask the question, what is the overall impact of all those projects and that makes it interesting to a country case for Slovenia tries to connect all stakeholders as well as being explained by the Minister and to connect all stakeholders around 1 theme which is opening up Slovenia and that is different from let's say, the mechanism that we know from Europe.
And of course I've been involved myself.

And running projects for this European money, but I'm I'm quite happy with this new initiative and with this maybe new idea for funding, and I'm sure that by having this more orchestrated approach the impact will be much higher.
You can get around, it must be higher because there is so much being invested in connecting all those stakeholders and I would like to call upon other countries in Europe.
Having opening up education from European Commission, what would it be good if more countries than only Slovenia would design such a country case?
They might be different and then to connect all those country cases and then to talk through the Commission about a secure funding for them.
And the last one is a wish that I would like to express.
We all have been witnessing bowling at the billing process for more than a decade, and I think we could say that Europe has.
Given a good example in the world, by taking this initiative as a big innovation, you really must say that this is an extremely big innovation for higher education in Europe.
And why did it work?

You may wonder, and I seem to Commissioner was referring to the top down and bottom up combination, and that was certainly happening with Bologna Top down was there from the Commissioner from governments and bottom of there was a lot of feeling that it was time to do something.
And the goals were also quite clear.
We should harmonize the higher education model.
We shoot a worker mobility and we should work on quality.
Those three major goals and you may ask the question whether these conditions also apply to opening up education and then not only for higher education for all education along Europe.
And I seem to Commissioner made first statement already top down and bottom up is coming together.
So the first condition is being fulfilled.
I have the feeling there is also this idea of urgency.
In Europe, among many people and among many institutions, seeing what's happening with the books, of course, that is certainly contributing to urgency and also the common goals.

You could define pretty easily, and the goals could be to improve and increase Accessibility of education, quality of education, efficiency of education, and the sustainability we all think that odr world has to prove it all we are is more sustainable than the current system.
But almost like to quote my colleague UNESCO chair, and held a basket in Canada.
He says why do we have to defend that?
I think it's the other way around and the current system is not sustainable anymore.
So all we are an opening up education.
We may I can prove this, but it's it's applaudable thing.
I can argue that we can make the system more accessible, more of higher quality, more efficient and more sustainable.
And so the Commissioner.

It's one of her is, I think in one of her last actions as a Commissioner, and I think you can be proud of having initiated opening up education and maybe in 10 years from now we can say the same that we say today about Bologna.
This is a process, an exciting expedition that started last year and has since been is giving a very good contribution to that and I'm quite happy to be here and to share with you those five modest.
Observations, thank you very much.
And don't forget my last slide.
There's a summary, so education wide for broad benefits.
Governmental policies for full benefit.
And there is an umbrella term which brings into once it's about ego funding that could be different for leading to more impact, and it's allowed.
Bologna and.
Don't forget to touch.
